narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: NA
Nothing this class was terrible
I learned almost nothing in this class. Unfortunately the class barely covered any material and the professor failed to communicate with the class and answer questions.
The subject of the class was interesting, hearing about different philosophers and their arguments.
N/A

Vigorous writing. I also gained insight into the philosophy of AI. Despite Professor Gerlernter's insistence on by the book writing, his passion for the subject and his obvious talent and interest in writing well helped me improve my writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Better insight on grading
The professor needs to start grading fairly
Very little writing, good for stem students.

This course was not structured in a way to promote learning. The entire class was based on the opinions of the professor and four short papers covering very similar ideas. We were asked to write five assignments, four of which were only 150 words. We have still only received feedback on two of these assignments as of the day before term grades are due. The professor failed to answer any emails throughout the entire semester, including emails containing questions. I often tried to ask questions during class, but we were either muted or the professor could not hear us trying to ask him questions.
The professor did not give any feedback past the first two assignments, getting grades back at some point or even a few comments about an assignment would be nice.

Make Office Hours available weekly, even via zoom. We didn't finish all of our material each day and it would have been nice to follow up on some of the themes and ideas we addressed but didn't get a chance to explore.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: None applied
Shorter class times
recording the lectures would be good.

None of the practices succeeded. There was absolutely no communication during the class. Rarely wee my questions answered or even heard during class and they were never answered over email. Our grades on assignments were also not returned in an appropriate amount of time or ever returned at all.
I think in person classes would suit this class much better. There wasn't much discussion amongst us and most of us had our screens off in class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, for low work writing credit but be prepared for a hit on your GPA
Take pass fail. Only 2-3 students out of 25 or 30 get A's. Grading is absolutely ridiculous. He grades sentences based off of what he thinks sounds better, which makes it impossible to please him.
No the professor was horrible but the material was fun to learn
Yes to students who want easy writing credit
No very difficult to even understand what the professor wants from his papers. Very low workload BUT be warned.
I would not recommend this course to anyone else. I took nothing away from it other than the story of having taken it.

It is an interesting topic and provides writing credits, but that's where the recommendation ends. The professor does not respond to email and did not submit grades past the second assignment (out of 4 + final). The class itself was mostly listening to him ramble about people and their ideas, which was admittedly interesting at some points. Overall the comments that other people have about only taking this class if you don't care about your grade seem to be true.

Only if they are keen on sharpening their writing and have a strong interest in the philosophy of AI. This course was, to put it in words used by the professor, an "ambush." Once we got our first assignment things became more difficult, suddenly there were stakes. It would be helpful to introduce the assignment earlier in the class.
